rows.description: Beginning in mid-eighteenth-century Britain and spreading to the rest of the world through the early twentieth century, this period marks a switch from an agrarian society to one dominated by industries and machinery. It saw the development of coal-powered steam engines, railroads, machined parts, and factories.

rows.name: Late Industrial Revolution
rows.description: The second half of the Industrial Revolution encompassed the first half of the twentieth century and saw the development of petroleum as a fuel source, automobiles, and aircraft.

rows.name: Atomic Age
rows.description: This age began with the emergence of atomic weapons in World War II and followed on with nuclear power plants. It covered the Cold War and the dominant threat of mutually assured destruction, ending with the fall of the Soviet Union.

rows.name: Space Age
rows.description: This age marks the early days of space exploration, from simple satellites, to crewed spaceflight and the moon landing, and up through the beginning of the twenty-first century. It also marks the development of jet-engine and rocket technology and the related social developments due to cheap and expanding air travel.

rows.name: Information Age
rows.description: This age represents the shift in the late twentieth century and beyond to industries based on information technology. It includes rapid and culture-shifting computing and technological advancements.

rows.name: Interplanetary Age
rows.description: Civilization leaves Earth and spreads across the solar system. Space travel is difficult and time-consuming, with trips between planets taking weeks or months. Rudimentary terraforming technology may be implemented on worlds such as Mars and Venus, taking centuries to realize. Humanity begins mining asteroids and planetoids for valuable resources.

rows.name: Transhuman Age
rows.description: Cybernetic enhancement and genetic manipulation or augmentation becomes commonplace and dominates everyday living. Unenhanced individuals are dismissed or pitied, as most of humanity becomes transhuman.

rows.name: Intergalactic Age
rows.description: Faster-than-light travel allows humanity to reach beyond its solar system and visit the rest of the galaxy. The invention of FTL technology heralds other marvelous inventions that may seem almost magical to modern society, such as gravity manipulation, macroengineering of planetary megastructures, and the manipulation of force or energy fields.

rows.name: Quantum Age
rows.description: Technology advances to a point where the large-scale of manipulation of matter on an atomic and astronomical level becomes possible. Stellar mega-structures such as ringworlds, Dyson spheres, and matrioshka brains become commonplace, civilizations are established on a galactic scale, and species transcend mortality or even physical existence.

rows.name: The Psychic Awakening
rows.description: Humans unlock an ability to use psychic powers such as telekinesis and telepathy, and even more esoteric abilities such as pyrokinesis, divination, and astral projection. The direction of human advancement shifts from pursuing technological advancements to enhancing the powers of an individual's mind. Many technologies are replaced by psychic abilities.

rows.name: Mere Moon
rows.description: This world is small enough to be the satellite of a much larger world that dominates its skies. This larger world is likely a gas giant, but could be a solid planet instead. Characters add {@dice boost} to checks they perform on this world that involve physical activity.

rows.name: Small World
rows.description: This world is small enough that gravity is less than normal, leading to larger-than-usual plants and animals, as well as soaring geological formations impossible on a higher-gravity world. Characters add {@dice boost} to checks they perform on this world that involve physical activity

rows.name: Earthlike Planet
rows.description: This world matches our own in size and mass, and even has one or two large moons that create tides. You can use Earth as a template when creating this world.

rows.name: Large World
rows.description: The planet is very large and has a great deal of mass. Things here may be squat and incredibly strong to resist the pull of extreme gravity, and geological features may be smoothed and flattened after collapsing under their own weight. Characters add {@dice setback} to checks they perform on this world that involve physical activity.

rows.name: Rings
rows.description: This planet has a prominent ring system. If the world is technologically advanced enough, it may interfere with space travel.

rows.name: Tidally Locked World
rows.description: This planet is gravitationally locked with its star, meaning that one side is always in daylight, and the other is in perpetual darkness. The day side may be incredibly hot to the point of being uninhabitable, and the night side is likely to be impossibly cold. Life as we know it may only exist in the "twilight zone" running around the planet, where the sun is low in the sky.

rows.name: Artificial Construction
rows.description: This planet is some sort of fantastic artificial structure. It may be a huge ring that spins for gravity and maintains a biosphere on the inner edge, a gigantic Dyson sphere with civilization on the inside or on the outside, or something stranger like a disk, a pocket dimension, or a construction that completely defies the laws of physics (or even needs magic to exist).

rows.name: Searing Temperatures
rows.description: The world's median temperatures are very hot; too warm for comfort except to hardy life that has specifically evolved to deal with the heat. This world is likely to have extensive deserts, oppressively humid rainforests near sources of water, and seas full of salts and minerals. Characters add {@dice setback|2} to any checks they perform outside because of the extreme heat.

rows.name: Hot World
rows.description: Most of the world tends towards hotter-than-average climates, though some regions may be temperate or cool. This world is more likely to have deserts, savannas, plains, lush jungles, and tropical biomes. Characters add {@dice setback} to any checks they perform outside because of the heat.

rows.name: Temerate World
rows.description: This world sees a wide range of temperatures across its surface, but most regions tend to be comfortable for human life. This world is likely to have a wide range of biomes, ranging from the tropical to the arctic.

rows.name: Cold World
rows.description: The world tends towards cooler-than-average climates. While a few regions and microclimates may be temperate or even hot, most of the planet is cool or cold. This world is more likely to have alpine meadows, coniferous and hardy deciduous forests, taiga, tundra, and colder seas and oceans. Characters add {@dice setback} to any checks they perform outside because of the cold.

rows.name: Frozen Wastes
rows.description: The world is so cold that it can barely support life. Only rare regions have liquid water, and the life that has evolved on this world has specific ways of dealing with the cold. Most of this world is likely to be covered in snow, ice, glaciers, and other arctic conditions. Characters add {@dice setback|2} to any checks they perform outside because of the extreme cold.

rows.name: Fractured Land
rows.description: This region has been split and fractured by some sort of cataclysm: violent earthquakes, volcanoes, other geological effects, or something stranger or even supernatural. In any case, this region is unstable and dangerous.

rows.name: Wasteland
rows.description: A wasteland can be a frozen tundra, or a scorching desert. In either case, it is defined by its lack of liquid water, its extreme temperatures, and its hostility to life.

rows.name: Forest
rows.description: The one element common to all forests is a large number of trees. Beyond that, a forest can be a tropical rainforest, deciduous forest, or pine taiga. You could even have oversized mushrooms, gigantic creeper vines, or even stranger plants.

rows.name: Plains
rows.description: Plains are typically some form of grassland, savanna, scrubland, plateau, or other expanse of flattened ground. The plants tend to be grasses or bushes, with few trees to be found.

rows.name: Mountains
rows.description: Mountains can be found as vast ranks of serried peaks, a few rocky outcroppings, or even a single massive summit. Cliffs and steep rockcovered slopes make up much of this environment, punctuated by swift-flowing streams, high-altitude meadows, and hardy plant and animal life.

rows.name: Swamp
rows.description: Swamps are wet, waterlogged environments full of sluggish, stagnant water. They tend to be full of disease and decay, but also teeming living creatures who have adapted to live in them.

rows.name: River Valley
rows.description: The region is dominated by a single massive river and the lands that drain into it. The land around the river is likely to be flat and may be prone to flooding. If there are inhabitants, they likely use it for trade and travel.

rows.name: Ocean
rows.description: The region is a vast ocean, or an ocean and the coastal regions alongside it. Most life is aquatic, and any inhabitants either live under the water or spend a lot of time on the water.

rows.name: Lake
rows.description: The region is dominated by a large, freshwater lake. The lake is big enough that crossing it can take days, and local inhabitants probably spend a lot of time on, in, or under the water.

rows.name: Landmark
rows.description: This region is dominated by a notable landmark, such as a huge canyon, an extensive network of caves, a massive crater, huge glaciers, a towering mountain, gorgeous ocean reefs, or an active volcano. Roll on this table again, rerolling this result. Once you have determined an environment for this region, pick a suitable landmark to put in it.

rows.name: Uninhabited
rows.description: There are no people (whether human or other sentient species) living in this region.

rows.name: Isolated Low-Tech Groups
rows.description: This region is mostly uninhabited, but a few small tribes, families, or bands of people live here, cut off from the rest of your world. Reduce the technology level of people in this region by two steps (for example, if the rest of your setting is in the Iron Age, the inhabitants of this region would have Stone Age technology).

rows.name: Scattered Individuals
rows.description: This region is mostly uninhabited, but a few brave individuals do live here. They may live on isolated farmsteads, in hunting lodges, or simply in homes away from any major population centers. However, no towns or hamlets exist.

rows.name: Small Communities
rows.description: This region has some small towns or hamlets, with scattered homes or farms in between. The population centers tend to be only a few hundred people at the most.

rows.name: Midsized Towns
rows.description: This region has some moderately sized towns with smaller towns or hamlets on their outskirts. The population centers tend to be a few thousand people. If your technology level is Stone Age, consider rerolling this result.

rows.name: City
rows.description: This region has one major city with a population measured in the tens of thousands or more. It also has several small or mid-sized towns scattered throughout the region. If your technology level is Stone Age, consider rerolling this result.

rows.name: Cities
rows.description: This region has several large cities. Each has a sizable population that may be measured in the tens or hundreds of thousands (maybe millions). The region is heavily urbanized and developed. If your technology level is Medieval or lower, consider rerolling this result.

rows.name: Megalopolis
rows.description: This region is completely urbanized into a single, massive city with millions of inhabitants. Little remains of the natural elements of this region, unless they are artificially preserved. If your technology level is Late Industrial Revolution or lower, consider rerolling this result.

table.name: Table I.4-7: Other Inhabitants and Oddities
table.subtitle: Trait - Setting - Inhabitants and Oddities

rows.name: Warlike Wanderers
rows.description: This region is plagued by wandering groups of warlike nomads. It is difficult, if not impossible, to treat with these groups or negotiate with them. They either avoid being engaged in a pitched battle with military forces or are too strong to defeat militarily.

rows.name: Sky Islands
rows.description: Mountain-sized chunks of rock float above this region. They are so large that they have entire ecosystems that grow and develop on them. Local inhabitants may have explored these rocks and built communities on (or inside) them.

rows.name: Megafauna
rows.description: This region has populations of extremely large animals living in it. At minimum, they are the size of the largest dinosaurs from Earth's history, but they could be even bigger! Some may have been domesticated by local inhabitants, but others may pose a threat

rows.name: Spectacular Natural Beauty
rows.description: This region is extremely beautiful, a jewel of nature. Locals treasure the resplendence that they live among, and other individuals journey to this region to bask in its splendor.

rows.name: Megaflora
rows.description: The plant life in this region grows to be extremely large. It could include trees kilometers tall and tens of meters wide, fungi the size of houses, vines that choke square kilometers of land, and other plants big enough to build homes inside.

rows.name: The Pit
rows.description: A bottomless pit sits in a prominent location in this region. Nobody knows how it came to be, or whether it's natural or artificial. Any attempts to map it or find out how deep it is have failed so far.

rows.name: Valuable Resource
rows.description: An extremely valuable resource of your choosing exists in this region. It may make the locals rich, or it may cause outsiders to venture into the region to exploit them.

rows.name: Incomprehenseble Intelligence
rows.description: The local inhabitants share the region with some sort of other life that, while seemingly intelligent, is so different that interacting with it is impossible. This life is not hostile to the locals, although its actions are so apparently arbitrary that it may do things that put the locals in danger. Why and how the local inhabitants and this other life form coexist is up to you.

rows.name: The Ruins of Elder Races
rows.description: This region is dominated by the ruins from some older species or previous culture. Their technology was likely more advanced than that of the current inhabitants, or at least their constructions remain marvels of engineering that dominate the terrain.

rows.name: Gestalt Life Form
rows.description: Nearly all local life in the region is linked psychically or biologically, so that it actually is all part of one vast organism. This doesn't apply to the local inhabitants of the society you generated, but it does apply to everything else.

rows.name: Elaborate Cave System
rows.description: : Underneath the ground in this region is an extensive and extremely elaborate cave system. The system has its own complex ecosystem, and local inhabitants may even live within the caves.

rows.name: Localized Anomalies
rows.description: For some reason, physics don't quite behave correctly in some parts of this region. Gravity may be stronger or weaker than normal, time may move more quickly or more slowly in some places, or even stranger things may occur.

rows.name: Secret Base
rows.description: An organization that has no local ties to the region has set up some sort of facility in it. Roll once on {@table I.4-10: Factions and Organizations} to find out what organization it might be. Whatever it is, its members actively discourage anyone from becoming involved in their business.

rows.name: Dragons
rows.description: The region is home to several giant and intelligent lizards who fly and breathe fire. They have their own culture and society, and they regard the other local inhabitants with some mixture of annoyance, disdain, or active dislike.

rows.name: Constant Storms
rows.description: The region is plagued by continuous storm systems that are powerful and violent.

rows.name: Site of a Great Historical Event
rows.description: Long ago, something incredibly important happened in a location in this region. This could be a battle, the signing of a treaty, or a scientific or philosophical discovery. Whatever it was, a monument has been erected to memorialize it.

rows.name: War Zone
rows.description: This region is plagued by constant (if potentially intermittent) war between two factions. Locals work hard to try and survive the battles and skirmishes going on around them.

rows.name: Monastery
rows.description: An organization has set up a monastery or retreat of some sort in the region. Roll once on {@table I.4-10: Factions and Organizations} to find out what organization this might be. The organization's members are welcoming and open about their presence and work hard to be good neighbors.

rows.name: The Hunter
rows.description: Something lives in this region that hunts the inhabitants for some reason. This thing may be a creature, a person, or something stranger (perhaps a ghost or an artificial being). Whatever it is, society has been unable to eliminate it and is forced to live around it instead.

rows.name: No Divine Spark
rows.description: Religion is entirely absent from this setting. There are no gods and no beliefs in the divine. Instead, societies are secular. It is up to you whether religious beliefs did exist once but have been forgotten or excised, or if your setting never had a belief in the divine.

rows.name: Polytheistic Pantheon
description: This religion focuses around a pantheon of powerful deities, each of which has a different portfolio of responsibilities. These responsibilities may be natural phenomena or features (oceans, mountains, thunder, rain), concepts (war, peace, justice, knowledge, beauty), or a combination of both. However, each god has a different responsibility or responsibilities, so societies likely believe in and worship the pantheon as a whole. Meanwhile, individuals believe in the pantheon, but tend to pray to the deity who is most relevant to their current situation (farmers pray to a god of fertility and bounty, while soldiers pray to a god of war, for example).

If you choose or roll this result, roll a further d10 die. On a 1, your pantheon is composed entirely of good deities. On a 2-5, your pantheon is composed of a mix of good and evil deities. On a 6-9, the deities in your pantheon are amoral, neither good nor evil. And on a 10, your pantheon is composed entirely of evil deities. It's up to you to interpret what good and evil means in your setting.

rows.name: World Spirit
rows.description: This religion believes that all of the souls or spiritual energies of all living things on a world combine into a single gestalt "world spirit." This spirit's motives may be inscrutable, and it may not have a personification or communicate with people. However, the religion promotes the idea that all lives are linked, and balance and harmony with nature and the wider world are likely to be important concepts.

rows.name: Many Spirits
rows.description: This religion believes that most things have a spirit that is a discrete and identifiable entity. Things with a spirit include people, animals, and plants, but also rivers, mountains, forests, fields, and crafted items. This religion may draw the line at mass-produced, disposable, or consumable items, but anything with a significant presence in the physical world also has a significant presence in the spiritual one.

rows.name: Monotheistic Religion
description: This religion venerates a single deity. The deity may be visualized as an ideal form of the principal species that worships it, or it may be more of a concept or an idea. The deity may take an active role in directing its followers' lives, or it may grant its followers free will and the autonomy to do what they want. Whatever the case, this deity is the source and example of any divine power in the setting.

If you choose or roll this result, roll a further d10 die. On a 1-4, your deity is good. On a 5-8, your deity is amoral, neither good nor evil. On a 9-0, your deity is evil. It's up to you to interpret what good and evil means in your setting.

rows.name: Anarchy
rows.description: Here, there is no organized political structure. Everyone looks out for themself, their family, and their friends, without any larger government at work. If your setting is Iron Age or higher, you may consider rerolling this result (unless your setting is post apocalyptic).

rows.name: Local Rulers and Councils
description: This is slightly more organized than pure anarchy. Here, government exists on a small scale, with groups of several hundred people electing mayors and councils, being ruled by hereditary lords, or following the banner of small, enterprising warlords. It is up to you what form your social groups take (small townships, roving tribes, or even neighborhoods in a larger city, for example).

If you choose or roll this result, roll a d10 die (either for the region as a whole, or for each social group individually). On a 1-4, your social groups are mostly democratic and elect their leaders. On a 5-8, your social groups are controlled by hereditary rulers. On a 9-0, your social groups are organized around charismatic or terrifying warlords and bandit kings.

rows.name: City-States
description: Here, each city is also its own state. Cities control the territory around them, trade with their neighbors, make war on their enemies, and generally perform all the tasks of a national government on a more limited scale. Forms of the various city-states' governments may be wildly different, or they may follow a similar pattern across the region or world. If your setting is Stone Age, consider rerolling this result.

If you choose or roll this result, roll a d10 die (either for the region as a whole, or for each city-state individually). On a 1-3, your citystates practice direct or representative democracy. On a 4-6, your city-states are controlled by hereditary rulers. On a 7-8, your city-states are controlled by guilds or other organized interest groups. On a 9-10, your city-states are run by nonelected individuals who have power through money, military backing, or other means that are not necessarily hereditary.

rows.name: Nation-States and Nations
description: Nation-states are larger than city-states, and they often control several cities and other population centers within their borders. However, each individual nation-state has a shared culture and ethnic heritage, which may vary wildly from nation-state to nation-state. Alternatively, your governments may be organized into nations that host multiple cultures and ethnicities in their borders and are unified under a shared history or an ideal, rather than a shared culture. If your setting is Bronze Age or lower, consider rerolling this result.

If you choose or roll this result, roll a d10 die (either for the region as a whole or for each nation-state individually). On a 1-3, your nationstates practice direct or representative democracy. On a 4-6, your nation-states are controlled by hereditary rulers. On a 7-8, your nationstates are controlled by guilds or other organized interest groups. On a 9-10, your nation-states are run by nonelected individuals who have power through money, military backing, or other means that are not necessarily hereditary (these can either be open—and probably totalitarian—rulers, or you can roll again to see what kind of government these individuals manipulate clandestinely).

rows.name: World Government
description: Here, the world is unified under a single government. Society likely has multiple cultures and ethnicities coexisting side by side (though not necessarily harmoniously). If your setting is a single region on a world, this may apply to the region, or your region may be a small part of a larger government. If your setting is multiple worlds, this result can represent a multi-world governmental system. If your setting is Bronze Age or lower, consider rerolling this result.

If you choose or roll this result, roll a d10 die. On a 1-4, your world government is mostly democratic or representatively democratic. On a 5-8, your world government is controlled by a hereditary ruler. On a 9-0, your world government is a mix or derivative of both (perhaps an elected leader-for-life, a hereditary ruler who must be approved by representatives of the population, or a totalitarian ruler who is not hereditary).

rows.name: Academics
rows.description: Individuals dedicated to learning and research, who may band together to work against corporate exploitation or government restrictions. An academic faction may have ties to some institute of learning or repository of information, but likely is loosely organized, without a strict hierarchical structure.

rows.name: Caste System
rows.description: Social stratification of a society based on heredity. Members of the same caste may support each other and may work to protect or counter the caste system itself. Caste systems can be formalized in a legal system or can be purely social constructs. They can exist without a more organized structure, since someone is either born into a caste or not.

rows.name: Clans
rows.description: Traditionally, clans are based on an extended family grouping. However, a clan may extend beyond family ties, either through some sort of pro forma adoption system or through an oath of allegiance. Most clans are hierarchical in nature, with a patriarch, matriarch, or other elder holding most of the authority.

rows.name: Corporation
rows.description: A formal business with executives, board members, officers, employees, and usually stockholders and investors. Corporations can be relatively small companies to international, nongovernmental organizations.

rows.name: Fans/Fanatics
rows.description: Fans of specific sports teams, cultural elements, pop culture, and influential companies can band together over their common interests and may struggle against similar groups that do not share their beliefs. Fan organizations can be structured or chaotic.

rows.name: Guild
rows.description: An organization of merchants or tradespeople could be a monopoly designed to corner the market on a particular item or items. Alternatively, a guild could be a loose collective of individuals who just want to look out for one another when a greater threat looms. In both cases, it is loosely structured, since the merchants are nominally still competing with each other

rows.name: Military
rows.description: Most militaries operate under government control, though personal security, paramilitary, and mercenary groups may exist outside of governments. Militaries tend to follow a very strict hierarchy, with professional codes of conduct.

rows.name: Pirates
rows.description: A pirate "faction" may be limited to a single ship and its crew, but larger organizations are possible if the pirates have a common enemy that they need to rally against. The leadership of a larger pirate organization is likely determined based on which pirate captains are the most charismatic or terrifying (or both).

rows.name: Political Faction
rows.description: A group or individuals who share common overall political viewpoints but are not necessarily formal members of a political party. Issue-based factions can cross major political party lines.

rows.name: Rebels or Terrorists
rows.description: Groups working towards the violent overthrow of an organization or government. A rebellion might wage a guerrilla campaign of terrorism, sabotage, and hit-and-run attacks against a government, in which case it is likely disorganized and fractured. Alternatively, it might be a large group of people with a sizable territory that splits off from a larger state and has infrastructure, organization, and even something of a standing army.

rows.name: Religions Organizations
rows.description: A group of believers or individuals with the same religious beliefs. The level of organization in this group depends on the level of organization in the religion as a whole, and can range from a strong hierarchy to very disorganized. This could also be a smaller faction within a wider religious group. In that case, they may support reform ideas, have liturgical differences, and support or oppose specific leaders.

rows.name: Union
rows.description: A group of workers or employees in a capitalist system who have banded together to lobby for better working conditions, increased compensation, or other benefits. Their collective bargaining power is their primary strength, as they can threaten to stop an industry if their demands are not met. Unions require at least a certain amount of organization to be effective.

rows.name: Assassination
rows.description: The organization attempts to secretly murder influential individuals to eliminate anyone who threatens its existence.

rows.name: Economic Growth
rows.description: The organization is maximizing its potential for monetary earnings. Its means of doing so may include acquisitions, bribery, political influence, or complex deal making.

rows.name: Exploration
rows.description: The organization wants to explore specific regions for raw materials, new discoveries, isolated societies, and glory.

rows.name: Illicit Activities
rows.description: Criminal syndicates run rackets such as smuggling, gambling, or extortion or take similar measures to make money and control certain areas or types of operations.

rows.name: Investigation
rows.description: The organization carries out investigations of controversial or criminal activities in order to protect the public or to further other objectives.

rows.name: Law Enforcement
rows.description: The organization enforces the laws of the land. Corrupt forces or individuals may use their position to exploit those they are supposed to protect.

rows.name: Military Expansion
rows.description: The organization expands its power using military means, such as invasions and conquests.

rows.name: Monopoly
rows.description: The organization seeks to corner the market for specific goods and services.

rows.name: Overthrow
rows.description: The organization seeks to overthrow the head of a government or other powerful entity.

rows.name: Protection
rows.description: The organization seeks to protect a specific group of people or allied organizations.

rows.name: Research
rows.description: The organization researches specific subjects to facilitate cutting-edge scientific, technological, or medical developments.

rows.name: Territory
rows.description: The organization seeks to expand the territory it controls or influences and to protect what it already has.

rows.name: Terrorism
rows.description: Terrorist organizations are trained and funded to achieve change through violent attacks against the population.

rows.name: Amicable
rows.description: This person is friendly and easygoing. They prefer to work in cooperation with others rather than against them.

rows.name: Cowardly
rows.description: This person is primarily motivated through fear, whether it's fear for themself or fear of losing what they care about.

rows.name: Caring
rows.description: Compassion for those around them motivates this character's actions. This caring may not extend to people outside of their organization

rows.name: Courageous
rows.description: Fear has no place in this person's heart. When faced with a decision, they always stand up for themself, no matter the odds stacked against them. If given a choice to fight a foe or flee (or make a deal), they always choose to fight.

rows.name: Calculating
rows.description: The mind of this individual is like a computer, always factoring odds and probabilities and able to remember the smallest details. They maintain their power through logic and information.

rows.name: Dreadful
rows.description: This person uses fear to motivate enemies and allies alike. They are as ruthless and as cruel as they need to be to instill the proper fear.

rows.name: Clever
rows.description: This person has a sharp personality and is keen to play tricks and fool people into doing what they want. They always have a cunning plan in operation, and sometimes more than one.

rows.name: Serene
rows.description: A deep calm permeates this person's being. They may not be a leader in their organization, but they could be its spiritual heart.

rows.name: Charming
rows.description: This person operates by being friendly, which often makes other people like them and want to please them.

rows.name: Lighthearted
rows.description: This person is genuinely happy and carefree, and likely doesn't care much about maintaining power or status in their organization.

rows.name: Corrupt
rows.description: If you offer this person something valuable, it's likely they'll quickly betray their principles and their organization to do your bidding.

rows.name: Annoying
rows.description: This person has some sort of personality trait that most people find bothersome. Maybe it's the tone of their voice, the comments they make, or a bad habit (such as chewing too loudly), but whatever it is, it makes them hard to ignore.

rows.name: Frugal
rows.description: Saving and conserving is this person's primary concern. They're unlikely to offer aid or resources without careful consideration.

rows.name: Generous
rows.description: If there's something you need, this person is usually more than happy to help. They're willing to dole out the resources of their organization to help with a good cause.

rows.name: Ambitious
rows.description: The thing this person wants more than anything is to gain more authority in their organization.

rows.name: Excitable
rows.description: This person can bring a lot of enthusiasm to projects and their work, but they can also be easily distracted.

rows.name: Methodical
rows.description: Process and procedure are this person's watchwords. They always do everything in proper order and take their time to do it right.

rows.name: Suspicious
rows.description: This person always assumes that anyone they work with has an ulterior motive. They may welcome a true enemy, because at least that person or group is openly against them.

rows.name: Angry
rows.description: This person wakes up angry at the world, and that bleeds into their interactions with everyone. They scream at their allies, berate their underlings, and fly into a furious rage at their foes.

rows.name: Quietly Deadly
rows.description: This person seems calm, quiet, and mild mannered—but they do not hesitate to kill anyone who fails them or stands in their way.

effects: {@b Blur:} If the spell targets a character, it blurs and obscures their form. Until the spell ends, add {@symbols h} to the results of combat checks targeting the character (this applies even if the attacker realizes the effect is an illusion).

{@b Mirror Image:} If the spell targets a character, it creates multiple images that move with the target and distract opponents. Until the spell ends, the character may spend {@symbols hhh or d} from any combat check targeting them to cause the attack to harmlessly hit a mirror image rather than the character (this applies even if the attacker realizes the effect is an illusion).

{@b Additional Illusion:} The spell creates one additional illusion or disguises one additional character. In addition, after casting the spell, you may spend {@symbols aa} to create another additional illusion or disguise another additional character (you may trigger this multiple times, spending {@symbols aa} each time).
{@b Range:} Increase the range of the spell by one range band. This may be added multiple times, increasing the range by one range band each time.

{@b Size:} Increase the silhouette of the illusion created by one, or disguise the appearance of a target one silhouette larger. This may be added multiple times, increasing the silhouette of the illusion created or target disguised by one each time.

{@b Realism:} Increase the difficulty of checks to determine that the illusion is fake by one. In addition, after casting the spell, you may spend {@symbols aa} to increase the difficulty of checks to determine that the illusion is fake by one (you may trigger this multiple times, spending {@symbols aa} each time). The illusion can also fool additional senses such as smell, taste, or touch.

{@b Terror:} The illusion terrifies those who behold it. When any character who does not know the illusion is fake spots it, they must make a {@difficulty Hard|Discipline}. They suffer 2 strain per {@symbols h} and, if they fail, are unable to approach the illusion. (If you are using the Fear rules from page 243 of the {@title Genesys} Core Rulebook, this can be a {@difficulty Hard|fear}).
{@b Invisibility:} If the spell targets a character, it renders them invisible to sight instead of changing their appearance.

{@b Quicksilver Reflexes:} Instead of asking a question about events, the character adds {@symbols ss} to the results of any checks they make to {@rule determine Initiative||crb} during the next structured encounter they participate in.

{@b Scry:} Instead of asking a question about events, the character may learn the location of one silhouette 0 item within long range. They must know what item they are looking for before they cast the spell, and the spell does not reveal how to get through any obstacles such as locked doors, hidden passages, or traps.
{@b Empowered:} The character may ask a question about events that will unfold within the next month.

{@b Additional Questions:} The character may ask one additional question about events. In addition, after casting the spell, you may spend {@symbols aa} to ask another additional question about events (and may trigger this multiple times, spending {@symbols aa} each time).

{@b Flash of Perception:} In addition to asking a question, once before the end of the current encounter, the character may add {@symbols s} to the results of one of their checks. In addition, once before the end of the current encounter, the character may add {@symbols f} to the results of a check targeting them. In addition, after the character casts the spell, you may spend {@symbols a} to add {@symbols ss} to the results of one of their checks, and add {@symbols ff} to the results of a check targeting them, instead of this effect's normal benefits.

{@b Cheat Death:} In addition to asking a question, the character forsees a possible doom for themselves in the next 24 hours. Once before the end of the current session, when the character would otherwise be incapacitated or killed, you may spend a Story Point to have them suffer wounds and strain until they reach (but do not exceed) their wound and strain thresholds instead. Their survival should be described narratively, taking into account that they "saw" their potential death coming.
{@b Silhouette Increase:} The character may transform into an animal that is one silhouette larger (this may be added multiple times, increasing the silhouette by one each time).

{@b Characteristic Retention:} When transformed, the character retains their own {@characteristic Intellect||crb} and {@characteristic Willpower||crb}, rather than the {@characteristic Intellect||crb} and {@characteristic Willpower||crb} of the creature they transformed into.

{@b Transform Gear:} When the character is transformed, their worn gear and wielded items change into natural markings on the animal's skin, fur, or scales (but confer no benefit to the character). When the character reverts back to normal, they are wearing and carrying their gear and items.

{@b Dire Form:} When the character transforms, they adopt a dire form of the chosen animal. Increase the damage of the animal's weapons by three, its soak by one, its wound threshold by six, and its silhouette by one.

{@b Curse of the Wild:} Instead of transforming themself, the character may transform one target within short range into a silhouette 0 animal of the character's choice following all of the rules for transformation.

talent.name: Component Casting
description: When your character casts a spell, they may use this talent to consume a physical item and add {@dice boost} to the check. The item does not have to be expensive or rare, but it does have to be thematically appropriate for the spell, available to your character, and subject to your GM's approval. Some examples include a match or bit of sulphur for an {@spell Attack||crb} spell with the {@quality Burn||crb} quality, a piece of glass for a {@spell Predict} spell, or a scrap of bandage for a {@spell Heal||crb} spell.

talent.name: Elementalist
description: When your character purchases this talent, choose one of the following attack spell effects (and the element associated with it): Fire (fire), Ice (water), Impact (earth), or Lightning (air). Whenever your character casts an {@spell Attack||crb} spell, they always add the chosen effect to the spell without increasing the difficulty. However, they may never add any of the other three effects to a spell they cast.

talent.name: Ensorcelled
description: If your character has at least one rank in a magic skill, once per encounter, they may use this talent to add {@symbols a} to the result their next social skill check.

Additionally, this has a passive narrative effect; your character's appearance is subtly enhanced by their magic. Others do not note it as supernatural, but may be slightly put off. What form this enhancement takes is up to you, with your GM's approval, but it should be based on the magic skill your character possesses (as well as their backstory). A character with the {@skill Divine||crb} skill may always be flushed with good health, or their eyes may flash red momentarily. A character with the {@skill Primal||crb} skill may be surrounded by the scent of fresh pine, or their voice may have an intimidating growl. A character with the {@skill Arcana||crb} skill may have their hair tousled by undetectable winds, or when they wear a hat or hood, their face might be obscured by strangely deep shadows.

talent.name: Brilliant Casting
description: When your character casts a spell, you may spend one Story Point to use this talent to add {@symbols a} equal to your character's ranks in {@skill Knowledge||crb} to the results.

talent.name: Ensorcelled (Improved)
description: {@i Your character must have purchased the {@talent Ensorcelled} talent to benefit from this talent}. If your character has at least two ranks in a magic skill, when using the {@talent Ensorcelled} talent, they may add {@symbols sa} to their next social skill check (instead of {@symbols a}).

After purchasing this talent, your character's appearance is now noticeably changed by their magic. What form this enhancement takes is up to you, with your GM's approval, but it should be based on the magic skill your character possesses as well as the enhancement they originally possessed with the {@talent Ensorcelled} talent.

talent.name: Druid
description: When your character casts a {@spell Conjure||crb} spell using the {@skill Primal||crb} skill, they always add the Summon Ally effect without increasing the difficulty, and they must always summon a living animal (such as those starting on page 86). The animal remains for the duration of the encounter even if your character does not use a concentrate maneuver to maintain the spell. At your GM's discretion, the animal may have already been nearby rather than summoned from thin air. Likewise, at the end of the encounter, the animal may revert back to its natural behavior instead of vanishing.

talent.name: Elementalist (Improved)
description: {@i Your character must have purchased the Elementalist talent to benefit from this talent}. When your character purchases this talent, they gain one of the following abilities based on the element they selected when they purchased {@talent Elementalist}: they cannot be knocked prone or {@rule staggered||crb} (earth), they cannot be {@rule immobilized||crb} and can breathe underwater (water), they cannot be {@rule disoriented||crb} and can fly using the hovering guidelines in the {@sidebar Flying||crb} sidebar on page 100 of the {@title Genesys} Core Rulebook (air), or they are immune to fire - including ignoring damage from attacks with the {@quality Burn||crb} item quality and from other fire-based attacks (fire).

talent.name: Ensorcelled (Supreme)
description: {@i Your character must have purchased the {@talent Ensorcelled (Improved)|Improved Ensorcelled} talent to benefit from this talent}. If your character has at least three ranks in a magic skill, once per session they may use this talent to force all enemies within medium range to make a {@difficulty Hard|Discipline} as an out-of-turn incidental. If they fail, they must spend all available maneuvers moving away from your character, and they suffer 5 strain, plus 1 additional strain per {@symbols h} (if your group is using the optional Fear rules on page 243 of the Core Rulebook, this can be treated as a fear check).

What form this reveal takes is up to you, with your GM's approval, but is should be based on your character's magic skill and the enhancement they possess from the {@talent Ensorcelled (Improved)|Improved Ensorcelled} talent. Some possibilities include growing golden wings of light, manifesting demonic horns and glowing red eyes, rising into the air on a tornado, becoming a figure of pure shadow, or transforming into a massive treelike humanoid.

talent.name: Explosive Casting
description: When your character casts an {@spell attack||crb} spell, they treat the spell's {@quality Blast||crb} quality as having a rating equal to twice your character's ranks in {@skill Knowledge||crb} (instead of their ranks in {@skill Knowledge||crb}). When your character casts an {@spell Attack||crb} spell with the {@quality Blast||crb} effect, you may spend one Story Point to use this talent to trigger the spell's {@quality Blast||crb} quality, instead of spending {@symbols a} (even if the attack misses).

talent.name: Face of the Wild
description: When your character casts a {@spell transform} spell on themself using the {@skill Primal||crb} skill, you may spend a Story Point to have them use this talent to maintain the effects of the spell until the end of the encounter, without performing concentrate maneuvers.

talent.name: Innate Focus
description: While not using a magic implement, your character increases the base damage of all {@spell Attack||crb} spells they cast by two. In addition, when casting a spell while not using a magic implement, your character may use this talent to decrease the difficulty of the check by one. If they do so, they increase the strain suffered for casting the spell by one.

talent.name: Master of Illusion
description: After your character makes a successful {@spell Mask} spell to create an illusion, you may spend a Story Point to have your character use this talent to make the illusion last until the end of the encounter, without performing concentrate maneuvers, and not need to remain within the spell's range after being cast. You may spend two Story Points to make the illusion last until the end of the session instead.

talent.name: Elementalist (Supreme)
description: {@i Your character must have purchased the {@talent Elementalist (Improved)|Improved Elementalist} talent to benefit from this talent}. When your character casts an {@spell augment||crb}, {@spell barrier||crb}, or {@spell transform} spell, they may use this talent to choose to have the targets of the spell gain the ability your character gained when they purchased {@talent Elementalist (Improved)|Improved Elementalist} for the spell's duration.

talent.name: Flicker Step
description: When your character casts a spell using the {@skill Arcana||crb} skill, they may use this talent to spend {@symbols aaa or t} to instantly vanish and reappear at any location within long range.

talent.name: Masterful Casting
description: When your character casts a spell, they may use this talent to spend {@symbols t} to trigger up to three different qualities or spell effects instead of one. These qualities or spell effects must be ones that can be triggered by spending {@symbols a or t}.

talent.name: Polymorph
description: If your character has at least one rank in the {@skill Arcana||crb} or {@skill Divine||crb} skill, they can cast the {@spell transform} spell. However, they can use the spell to only transform into magical or supernatural creatures (such as dragons, angels, demons, or elementals).

talent.name: Strength of Faith
description: Once per session, your character may use this talent to add {@symbols s} equal to their ranks in {@skill Discipline||crb} and {@symbols a} equal to their ranks in Willpower to the results of the next {@skill Divine||crb} skill check they make during this turn.

talent.name: Teleportation
description: If your character has at least one rank in {@skill Arcana||crb}, once per session, your character may use this talent to make a {@difficulty Daunting|Arcana}. If they succeed, they instantly vanish and reappear in any other location in the world they already know about.

Your character may bring up to five allies with them when they teleport, but they must add {@dice setback} to the check for each ally. They may also teleport to different worlds or planes of existence; however, they must upgrade the difficulty of the check once (or more, at your GM's discretion) if they do so. Whenever your character uses this talent, your GM may spend {@symbols h} to have the teleportation miss the location by a range band per {@symbols h} spent, or may spend {@symbols hhhh or d} to have the teleportation go catastrophically wrong (by having a character materialize in a wall, another person, or midair, for instance, with the awful consequences to be determined by your GM).

talent.name: Dire Animal Companion
description: {@i Your character must have purchased the {@talent Animal Companion||crb} talent to benefit from this talent}. If your character has at least one rank in the {@skill Primal||crb} skill, the animal companion they have bonded with through the {@talent Animal Companion||crb} talent increases its Brawn by one, to a maximum of 5, and its wound threshold by four. If it is a nemesis, it increases its strain threshold by four. If it is a minion or rival, it becomes a nemesis and gains a strain threshold of 6. If it is silhouette 0, it becomes silhouette 1. Your character also chooses to increase either its Agility or its Willpower by one, to a maximum of 5, and its {@skill Brawl||crb}, {@skill Discipline||crb}, {@skill Perception||crb}, or {@skill Survival||crb} by one, to a maximum of 5.

talent.name: Teleportation (Improved)
description: {@i Your character must have purchased the {@talent Teleportation} talent to benefit from this talent}. Your character may use this talent to make a {@difficulty Hard|Arcana} to create a permanent beacon, glyph, or teleportation circle in a location (how it appears is up to you and your GM, but it should be large and noticeable).

When your character uses the {@talent Teleportation} talent, if they choose to teleport to the location of their beacon, glyph, or teleportation circle, the difficulty of the check is {@difficulty Average} and they do not add {@dice setback} for teleporting additional allies. They also do not upgrade the difficulty of the check to teleport to a different world or plane of existence.

Your character can have two glyphs, beacons, or circles established at any one time per rank of Improved Teleportation. If they create any over this limit, one of the originals of your character's choice is destroyed.

vehicle.name: Chariot
description: Chariots are two-wheeled vehicles drawn by two or four horses, used in ancient cultures as transportation for the nobility and for warfare and racing. Despite depictions in popular cinema, most war chariots served as mobile archery platforms for nobles, not as bladecovered battering rams. The chariot uses {@skill Riding||crb} as its control skill, but you can use {@skill Driving||crb} if you prefer (see {@sidebar Unorthodox Control Skills} on page 59).

vehicle.name: Coach
description: Coaches are covered, four-wheeled vehicles pulled by a team of two or more horses. Unlike wagons, coaches are designed for speed and transporting passengers. Coaches could range from the carriages of nobles to frontier stagecoaches. The coach uses {@skill Riding||crb} as its control skill, but you can use {@skill Driving||crb} if you prefer (see {@sidebar Unorthodox Control Skills} on page 59). You could also use this profile to represent a wagon by dropping the max speed to 1, reducing passenger capacity to 0, increasing encumbrance capacity to 60, and decreasing the price to 300.

vehicle.name: Motocycle
description: The motorcycle has been around since the earliest steampowered bicycles in the mid-1800s. The modern version is small, maneuverable, and fuel efficient, having seen civilian and military use for centuries. This profile can represent a Jet Ski in a modern setting, or if you change the control skill to {@skill Piloting||crb}, it can represent a hover bike (or hopperbike) in a science fiction setting.

vehicle.name: Sports Car
description: Often painted bright, attention-grabbing red, sports cars provide superior speed and handling at the expense of durability, safety, and passenger and cargo space.

vehicle.name: Bus
description: From ferrying children to forming the backbone of local public transit, the bus is a metropolitan people mover.

vehicle.name: Truck
description: Trucks are larger vehicles that haul loads of goods and supplies. This truck is midsized; it may need a higher encumbrance capacity to represent a semitruck.

vehicle.name: Locomotive
description: This profile might represent a classic steam engine; a more modern diesel, electric, or maglev train; or even a more futuristic design. Regardless, trains run on a prelaid track, and require certain crew members to activate track switches to manage their route.

description.title: Train Cars
entries: A locomotive usually hauls a number of train cars. Each car has the same hull trauma threshold, silhouette, defense, and armor as the locomotive and must be targeted individually. Passenger train cars can carry 100 people, while cargo train cars have an encumbrance capacity of 200. Each costs 5,000 currency

vehicle.name: Wasteland Buggy

abilities.name: Vulnerable
abilities.description: All successful combat checks targeting the wasteland buggy add {@symbols aa} to the results.

abilities.name: Spikey Bits
abilities.description: When the wasteland buggy is involved in a {@rule collisions|collision|crb} (see page 222 of the Genesys Core Rulebook) all other vehicles and characters involved in the collision add +30 to the results of any Critical Hit or Critical Injury they suffer.

description: In the wastelands of some post-apocalyptic settings, gangs of marauders have salvaged vehicles into rickety engines of destruction. Although these could take nearly any form, we have included an example built from the chassis of a pre-apocalypse automobile and heavily modified with weapons and a supercharged engine.

vehicle.name: Wasteland Nomad Rig

abilities.name: Resilient
abilities.description: When the wasteland nomad rig suffers a Critical Hit and your character is operating it, you may spend a Story Point to roll a second result and choose the result you prefer.

abilities.name: Spikey Bits
abilities.description: When the wasteland buggy is involved in a {@rule collisions|collision|crb} (see page 222 of the Genesys Core Rulebook) all other vehicles and characters involved in the collision add +30 to the results of any Critical Hit or Critical Injury they suffer.

weapons.name: 1 harpoon launcher
weapons.details: If target is silhouette 3 or less, gunner may spend {@symbols aa} or {@symbols t} from combat checks made with this weapon to move target one range band closer to the wasteland nomad rig.

description: Nomadic inhabitants of post-apocalyptic settings may roam the wastelands in salvaged semitrucks retrofitted into heavily armored rigs. These can also take nearly any form; this is a typical example.

vehicle.name: Armored Personnel Carrier
description: The APC is an armored (and usually armed) military vehicle designed to transport soldiers on the battlefield without getting them killed. Some APCs have been equipped to the point that they are almost miniature tanks, but the APC here represents a basic version.

abilities.name: All-Terrain
abilities.description: When making a {@skill Driving||crb} check to direct this vehicle, your character may remove {@dice setback|2} added to the check due to terrain.

vehicle.name: Tank
description: The armored tank rose to prominence in World War I, riding a pair of rugged treads capable of overcoming most obstacles. Its heavy armor makes the tank immune to most small-arms fire. It carries a main cannon capable of destroying armored vehicles and bunkers, as well as some defensive anti-personnel weaponry to keep enemy soldiers away

abilities.name: All-Terrain
abilities.description: When making a {@skill Driving||crb} check to direct this vehicle, your character may remove {@dice setback|2} added to the check due to terrain.

vehicle.name: Tactical Strider
description: The tactical strider is a medium-sized (six-meter-tall) pilotable humanoid mech. This profile could represent anything from a steam- and clockwork-powered walker, to a cumbersome military strider invented with weird science, to a powered suit neurally linked to the pilot. We've given ours a heavy rifle and a rocket pod.

abilities.name: All-Terrain
abilities.description: When making a {@skill Driving||crb} check to direct this vehicle, your character may remove {@dice setback|2} added to the check due to terrain.

vehicle.name: Mecha
description: Mechas are thirty-meter-tall humanoid vehicles that resemble gigantic power-armored soldiers. While most rely on a single pilot to operate via manual controls or AI assist, others use some form of neural interface technology, enabling pilots to treat the vehicle as an extension of their own body. They often wield scaled-up versions of personal weapons: huge swords, shields the size of rooftops, and rifles that look like heavy artillery pieces.

abilities.name: All-Terrain
abilities.description: When making a {@skill Driving||crb} check to direct this vehicle, your character may remove {@dice setback|2} added to the check due to terrain.

vehicle.name: Third-Rate Ship of the Line
description: Just under seventy meters long, third-rate ships of the line spread their guns across three decks. These sailing vessels were considered the premiere combat vessels of their day, balancing armament with maneuverability

vehicle.name: Longship
description: Infamously employed by Norse raiders, the longship is an iconic fifteen- to thirty-meter-long thin wooden ship with a single square sail. Offense is limited to the bows, slings, and spears of the warriors aboard.

vehicle.name: Trireme/Galley
description: The warships of antiquity, these vessels feature a large square sail and over a hundred oars. Soldiers on the top deck can launch projectiles and lead boarding actions. However, their main weapon is their fearsome ram.

abilities.name: Ram
abilities.description: When the trireme or galley deliberately collides with another ship (see {@rule collisions||crb} page 222 of the Genesys Core Rulebook), the other ship suffers 8 damage to its hull trauma threshold and adds +40 to the Critical Hit result it suffers. The trireme or galley reduces the results of the Critical Hit it suffers by -20.

vehicle.name: Small Cargo Freighter
description: Typically between sixty and ninety meters long, small freighters hire out independently to move cargo and passengers. This ship might be a river steamboat, an ocean cargo vessel, or a convoy ship in the midst of a war.

vehicle.name: World War II-Era Destroyer
description: Nearly one hundred and twenty-five meters long, destroyers target enemy ships with five-inch guns, launch torpedoes at larger warships, and also hunt submarines.

weapons.name: 2 forward and 2 aft 5-inch gun turrets
weapons.fireArc: (Forward, Port, and Starboard) or (Aft, Port, and Starboard)

weapons.name: 1 port and 1 starboard torpedo tube launcher
weapons.details: When making an attack with this weapon, spend an action to determine the dice pool, but do not make the check. Then, at the end of the round, make the combat check as an out-of-turn incidental. If the target is no longer in range or could not be hit by the attack for some other reason, the check fails.

vehicle.name: World War II-Era Battleship
description: For years, the ultimate weapon of the world's navies was the battleship, a massive ship carrying the largest cannons ever deployed at sea. They were a symbol of national pride as well as hideously expensive.

abilities.name: Massive
abilities.description: When making an attack targeting this vehicle, the Critical rating of any weapons used count as 2 higher.

weapons.name: 2 forward and 1 aft 16-inch gun turrets
weapons.fireArc: (Forward, Port, and Starboard) or (Port, Starboard, and Aft)

weapons.name: 20 forward, 20 aft, and 20 starboard 40mm anti-air guns
weapons.fireArc: Port or Starboard or Fore or Aft

vehicle.name: Submarine
description: From their concealed position under water, submarines can launch surprise attacks, gather intelligence, or infiltrate special forces units. This example uses guided torpedoes; if you want a military submarine from before the 1950s, remove the {@quality Guided||crb} item quality from the torpedo tube launchers, reduce the hull trauma threshold by ten, and change the crew compliment to 50 (reduce price by 40,000 as well).

weapons.name: 4 forward torpedo tube launchers
weapons.details: When making an attack with this weapon, spend an action to determine the dice pool, but do not make the check. Then at the end of the round, make the combat check as an out-of-turn incidental. If the target is no longer in range or could not be hit by the attack for some other reason, the check fails.

vehicle.name: Modern Frigate
description: Modern frigates escort larger ships and hunt submarines. They tend to have less armor, but they possess other defenses such as jamming systems, chaff rockets, and defensive weapons (represented by the ship's high defense rating).

weapons.name: 1 port and 1 starboard dual torpedo tube launcher
weapons.details: When making an attack with this weapon, spend an action to determine the dice pool, but do not make the check. Then at the end of the round, make the combat check as an out-of-turn incidental. If the target is no longer in range or could not be hit by the attack for some other reason, the check fails.

vehicle.name: Motorboat
description: The motorboat might be a speedboat, fishing boat, or a shallow water patrol boat (with some light guns).

vehicle.name: Motorboat (Patrol Boat)
description: The motorboat might be a speedboat, fishing boat, or a shallow water patrol boat (with some light guns).

vehicle.name: Guided Missile Cruiser
description: Modern cruisers take advantage of advanced radar equipment and anti-air missiles to protect whole fleets.

weapons.name: 1 forward and 1 aft 5-inch gun turret
weapons.fireArc: (Forward, Port, and Starboard) or (Aft, Port, and Starboard)

vehicle.name: Armored War Zeppelin
description: In some settings, zeppelins or other dirigibles have become the preeminent airborne vehicles. This is our take on a fanciful "war zeppelin," which sports turretmounted cannons and armored plates while still being "lighter than air." This type of vehicle would probably replace sea-going warships in the setting it's used in.

abilities.name: Massive
abilities.description: When making an attack targeting this vehicle, the Critical rating of any weapons used counts as 2 higher.

weapons.name: 1 forward and 1 aft twin 25-pound gun turret
2 port and 2 starboard 6-pounder defensive gun turrets
1 forward, 1 port, 1 starboard, and 1 aft defensive maxim gun

vehicle.name: Transport Zeppelin
description: This is our take on a steampunk setting's rigid airship that has been designed to transport cargo and passengers or is outfitted for exploration (hence the small armaments). It is somewhat fanciful, since it manages to be armored while still being an airship.

weapons.name: 1 port, and 1 starboard defensive maxim gun

vehicle.name: Cargo Plane
description: The cargo plane is a workhorse of air travel and logistics. Militaries use cargo planes to air-drop supplies, transport vehicles, and troops, and plenty of individuals use cargo planes to ship their goods around the globe.

vehicle.name: World War II-Era Fighter Plane
description: This is a prop-driven fighter aircraft from the 1940s designed to shoot down other fighter planes, escort heavy bombers, and attack ground targets. Fighters in this era typically had multiple machine guns (our fighter treats all of its guns as a single weapon system).

vehicle.name: World War II-Era Heavy Bomber
vehicle.complement: 1 pilot, 1 copilot, 1 navigator, 1 bombardier/gunner, 1 radio operator/gunner, 2 gunners
description: In World War II, heavy bombers were well equipped with defensive machine guns to drive off attacking fighters and could carry heavy payloads of explosives.

abilities.name: Bombing Run
abilities.description: The bombardier may pick a point on the ground beneath the bomber, then spend an action and perform a {@difficulty hard|Gunnery}. If the check is successful, all characters and vehicles within medium range of that point suffer a hit dealing 15 damage, plus 1 damage per {@symbols s}. The gunner may spend {@symbols a} or {@symbols t} to inflict a Critical Hit or Critical Injury on one vehicle or character affected by the bombing run, and may do so multiple times, selecting a different character or vehicle each time. At your GM's discretion, the bombing run may also destroy structures, shatter the landscape, or do other damage. Once this vehicle has made a bombing run, it cannot do so again until it has returned to base and has been reloaded with bombs.

weapons.name: Two twin heavy machine gun turrets

vehicle.name: Civilian Helicopter
description: Civilian helicopters transport VIPs, local news reporters, and police officers around cities.

vehicle.name: Helicopter Gunship
description: Attack helicopters support troops on the ground with close-in mobile firepower. Some rare variants can even transport soldiers into battle. To make this a transport gunship, reduce the handling by 2 and increase the passenger capacity to 8 (the cost remains unchanged).

vehicle.name: Helicopter Gunship (Transport)
description: Attack helicopters support troops on the ground with close-in mobile firepower. Some rare variants can even transport soldiers into battle. To make this a transport gunship, reduce the handling by 2 and increase the passenger capacity to 8 (the cost remains unchanged).

vehicle.name: Orbital Shuttle
description: Ground-to-orbit shuttles are essential to reach dedicated starships in space. Shuttles must be aerodynamic and armored or shielded for reentry.

vehicle.name: Interstellar Freighter
description: For every military starship, there are a thousand freighters transporting goods. Our take on the space freighter is similar to a small oceangoing freighter, with a small crew, large cargo holds, and limited maneuverability

vehicle.name: Space Cruiser
description: Intended for more futuristic settings, our take on the space cruiser might serve as a frontline combatant, enforce blockades, secure logistical routes, raid enemy supply lines, or conduct customs patrols.

abilities.name: Massive
abilities.description: When making an attack targeting this vehicle, the Critical rating of any weapons used counts as 2 higher.

weapons.name: 2 fusion missile launch tubes
weapons.details: When the {@quality Blast||crb} quality is triggered, all vehicles within medium range suffer a hit.

weapons.name: 10 heavy laster projectors
weapons.details: These weapons are scattered across the hull of the vessel, so only two may be fired at any one target.

vehicle.name: Long-Range exploration cruiser
description: Humanity's efforts to explore the stars—to investigate, map, and study alien planets and life forms—ultimately rely on large, deep-space exploration vessels. Given their long-term mission, these spacecraft carry scientists, family members, and even pets. Such ships are perfect as settings for an entire campaign.
